docs.lead_paragraph: In New York, a proposal for a “living wage” has become the occasion for high-profile soul-searching and head-scratching by the mayor and the City Council speaker.

headline.seo: No Money for a Living Wage? But Fat Abounds
headline.main: No Money for a Living Wage? But Fat Abounds
headline.print_headline: No Money for a Living Wage? But Fat Abounds

docs.abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column about how in New York City, a proposal for a 'living wage' has become the occasion for high-profile soul-searching and head-scratching by the mayor and the City Council speaker.
docs.snippet: In New York, a proposal for a “living wage” has become the occasion for high-profile soul-searching and head-scratching by the mayor and the City Council speaker.

docs.lead_paragraph: Members of Congress need to change their minds about compromise, or voters will need to change the members of Congress.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by professors Amy Gutmann and Dennis F Thompson notes that the failure of the budget supercommittee is only the latest breakdown in an attempt at compromise in Washington; argues that members of Congress need to learn how to reach a middle ground, or voters will use the next election to bring in members who care enough about governing to try to compromise.
docs.snippet: Members of Congress need to change their minds about compromise, or voters will need to change the members of Congress.

keywords.value: Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By AMY GUTMANN and DENNIS F. THOMPSON

docs.abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services issued the funds as part of the planning to set up exchanges for health insurance coverage.
docs.snippet: The Department of Health and Human Services issued the funds as part of the planning to set up exchanges for health insurance coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Hoping to alleviate concerns of states, the Obama administration on Tuesday said it would award nearly $220 million in new federal grants to states to set up exchanges where uninsured Americans may eventually be able to buy medical coverage as part of the federal health care law.
docs.abstract: The Department of Health and Human Services issued the funds as part of the planning to set up exchanges for health insurance coverage.
docs.snippet: The Department of Health and Human Services issued the funds as part of the planning to set up exchanges for health insurance coverage.

docs.lead_paragraph: Justices are expected to reject a request to allow live television coverage of the challenge to the health care law, but it is hard to say why.

headline.seo: Supreme Court TV? Nice Idea, but Still Not Likely — Sidebar
headline.main: Supreme Court TV? Nice Idea, but Still Not Likely
headline.print_headline: Supreme Court TV? Nice Idea, but Still Not Likely

docs.abstract: Adam Liptak Sidebar column examines why the Supreme Court is likely to reject a request to allow live television coverage of oral arguments in challenge to Pres Obama's health care law.
docs.snippet: Justices are expected to reject a request to allow live television coverage of the challenge to the health care law, but it is hard to say why.

docs.lead_paragraph: With increasingly sophisticated detection technology, dentists are finding — and treating — tooth abnormalities that may or may not develop into cavities.

headline.seo: A Closer Look at Teeth May Mean More Fillings by Dentists
headline.main: A Closer Look at Teeth May Mean More Fillings
headline.print_headline: Closer Look At Teeth May Mean More Filling

docs.abstract: Some dentists, using increasingly sophisticated detection technology, have begun to treat minor tooth abnormalities that may or may not develop into cavities; critics say practice is driving up cost of care, and that it causes unnecessary pain for patients.
docs.snippet: With increasingly sophisticated detection technology, dentists are finding — and treating — tooth abnormalities that may or may not develop into cavities.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee on Monday escalated its effort to define Mitt Romney, seeking the Republican nomination for president in 2012, as a flip-flopper with a new ad in five battleground states. Called ''Trapped,'' it is styled as a parody of a sci-fi movie trailer for ''the story of two men trapped in one body.'' THE SCRIPT

headline.main: The Ad Campaign: Democrats Take Aim at Romney's Shifts

docs.abstract: Ad Campaign column assessment and text of Democratic National Committee advertisement that paints Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney as a flip-flopper. Photo (M)
